Award.AwardTitle: Space Weather Workshop 2020; Boulder, Colorado; April 20-24, 2020
Award.AbstractNarration: The Space Weather Workshop is an inter-governmental agency sponsored meeting to bring together industry, academic, and government professionals for discussion of space weather. The aim of workshop is to discuss space weather impacts on communications, navigation, spacecraft operation, aviation, and electric power and identify what the highest priority operational needs are regarding these topics. The workshop fosters communication among researchers, space weather service providers, and users of space weather services. The proposal is to support administrative costs and student registration and housing for 17 students for the Space Weather Workshop to be held in Boulder, Colorado from April 20-24, 2020.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Space Weather Workshop is a premier meeting for the Space Weather community to share information and network with the industry, academia, and government agencies. It is co-sponsored by NOAA, NASA and NSF. As the nation's leading conference on all issues relating to space weather, the major goals of the April 20-22, 2021 workshop were to:

  • foster communication among researchers, space weather service providers, and users of space weather services
  • address the remarkable diverse impacts of space weather on today's technology
  • highlight space weather impacts in several areas, including communications, navigation, spacecraft operations, aviation, and electric power
  • identify the highest priority needs for operational services that can guide future research
  • identify new high-value research capabilities that can be transitioned into operations
  • provide for significant student participation that will help to develop the next generation of space weather professionals
  • emphasize the benefits of diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) through adhering to those principles in forming an organizing committee and meeting program

The meeting program can be found at NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center Website under the Annual Meeting link and going to prior workshops for the 2021 Meeting workshop agenda, or directly to: https://www.swpc.noaa.gov/sites/default/files/images/u63/2021 Space Weather Workshop Agenda With Links 15Jul2021.pdf

As discussed below, the workshop was successful in all of the above goals. It should also be noted that because of Covid-19, the 2021 meeting was held virtually. This format provided an opportunity to be more inclusive in both the program and the attendance. More participants and students were registered for this meeting than ever before, although the actual attendance at any one time was less than the total numbers [Registration: 1095 attendees including 193 graduate students and 55 undergraduates]
